title: 113_hr4123
content: The Act may be cited as the "Prohibiting Detention of Youth Status Offenders Act of 2014" and focuses on the deinstitutionalization of status offenders. Section 223 of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions regarding the placement of juveniles in secure detention facilities or correctional facilities. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for placing juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders, with specific requirements for issuing written orders detailing the violation and the lack of less restrictive alternatives. The amended Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act allows for juveniles to be placed in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders. The written order must specify the violation, lack of alternatives, limit the time to 3 days, and include a release plan. No renewals or extensions are allowed, and subsequent orders are prohibited. The amended Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act allows juveniles to be placed in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders. Procedures ensure juveniles do not remain in custody longer than 3 days or the time authorized by the court or state law. The amended Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act allows juveniles to be placed in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders, with restrictions on the frequency of secure custody. States may apply for extensions for compliance with the Act. States may apply for a one-year extension to comply with restrictions on placing status offenders in secure detention facilities. The application must demonstrate progress in reducing placements and outline a plan for compliance within the extension period.
